trial_identification.studytitle: Self controlled trial of Ambu Ascope for training clinicians in fibreoptic device guided intubation
trial_identification.scientifictitle: An evaluation of the Ambu Ascope for training clinicians in fibreoptic device guided orotracheal intubation as assessed using a Global Rating Scale

interventions.interventions: Ascope assisted orotracheal intubations will be performed on anaesthetised patients Operators given set of 5 Ascopes - operators are composed of 5 consultant anaesthetists and 3 anaesthesia registrars 1st to 5th attempt will be recorded on notebook PC. All attempts are carried out on different patients. Ascope will be used for each attempt GRS score evaluated on recordings

primaryOutcome.outcome: GRS score - Global Rating Scale - score of 1-5 to define bronchoscopic efficacy
primaryOutcome.timepoint: during performance of Ascope assisted intubation

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: during performance of Ascope assisted intubation
during performance of Ascope assisted intubation

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: able to consent for themselves general anaesthesia orotracheal intubation ASA I-III fasted for surgery
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: patients with indication for awake FOI inhalational induction known difficult/ impossible mask ventilation rapid sequence induction

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Ambu Australia Pty. Ltd. - Office 2401/4 Daydream St. NSW 2102 Warriewood

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This research is designed specifically to compare the performance before and after exposure to the Ambu Ascope in the clinical setting for scope guided intubation. Endpoints will be GRS score, success in intubation and time taken for intubation on the first and 5th attempts with Ascope. The null hypothesis for this research project is that there is no difference in GRS score before and after 5 attempts with Ambu Ascope
